The Deputy is asking the question I have asked a number of my taxi drivers. I have explored this quite a bit, and I used various different services to try to elucidate this a little.
There are three main reasons.

First, depending on the app or service, drivers either get told somebody is requesting a wheelchair taxi or that somebody is requesting a taxi. I will not say which is which but I have had much higher success rates when the drivers do not know I am specifically requesting a wheelchair taxi. The time it takes to load in as a single person is a massive issue. They are required, as far as I have understood from speaking to taxi drivers, to take one wheelchair passenger per week. I think what is happening is they are doing that but not going above and beyond that.

Why are they turning us down? It takes a little bit more time, as Ms Greham said. That has a deterrent effect. Sometimes they have the taxis but do not have the required training to operate the ramp, yet they are still allowed to designate it as a wheelchair taxi. Another issue is sometimes they are borrowing or lending taxis. Different companies have facilities to allow that but they are still registered as wheelchair taxis because the registration is for the taxi, not the driver. Those folks are turning up and do not have the training or are not normally in that position, so they are turning us down on that basis. Time, training and borrowing taxis are big reasons.

One way I can see this being addressed is not allowing taxi drivers to know whether somebody is requesting a wheelchair taxi or not. That is a simple solution and there is at least one company that does that. I have had the best success in getting wheelchair taxis from that company. We could create a system whereby that is across the board for all taxi companies. Alternatively, we could create a financial incentive for taking a person requesting a wheelchair taxi by offering an extra fee or subsidy covering the loading time. It is important that cost is not transferred onto the disabled person. That could be facilitated at State level if we wanted to make it a reality.

We are subsidising people to get wheelchair taxis through different schemes available so it is something the Government is supporting. That is good and beneficial. Many of us who have vehicles will, when we sell them, sell them to become taxis. That is a good system but we need to stop falling at the last hurdle. Government intervention can do that, as can working collaboratively with those companies.

This is also an issue for people using guide dogs or autistic support dogs. It is not purely a wheelchair-user issue. It is predominantly a wheelchair-user issue but is also faced when a taxi shows up and the driver sees a person with a support animal and drives off or refuses to take them in. That needs to be addressed when we talk about transport and access to employment.

Something I have heard a few times in relation to taxi drivers with the capacity to bring wheelchair users is that it is a fear thing. They have done the wheelchair clamp in training, technically, but the fear of God was put into them about doing it properly, or then they could get a different wheelchair from the one they trained on. It was a fear thing, which should not be an excuse if they are supposed to have capacity to bring someone with a wheelchair.

I thank the witnesses and members. That concludes round two. We will wrap up. Does anyone want to come in for an extra minute? No. That concludes our contributions from witnesses. I propose we publish all opening statements to the committee website. Is that agreed? Agreed. I thank everybody for attending, those in the committee room and those who joined online, and for their insightful contributions on access and employability. We as a committee are working on that for the next couple of weeks and will do a report on it. Hopefully, the witnesses' contributions will assist us greatly and I believe they will.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 11.24 a.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 12 November 2025.
